variant.question: Where on the curve in the image does the aeroplane exhibit neutral static longitudinal stability?
Where on the curve in the image does the aeroplane exhibit static longitudinal instability?
Where on the curve in the image does the aeroplane exhibit static longitudinal stability?

Which of the following statements about static longitudinal stability is correct?
1. A requirement for positive static longitudinal stability of an aeroplane is, that the neutral point is behind the centre of gravity
2. A wing with positive camber provides a positive contribution to static longitudinal stability, when the centre of gravity of the aeroplane is in front of the aerodynamic centre of the wing.

Which statement is correct? 

I Stall speeds are determined with the CG at the aft limit
 II Minimum control speeds are determined with the CG at the aft limit.

options.text: I is incorrect, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
I is correct, II is incorrect.
I is correct, II is correct.

variant.question:
Which statements are correct or incorrect?
1) Stall speeds are determined with the CG at the forward limit.
2) Minimum control speeds are determined with the CG at the aft limit.

Which statements are correct or incorrect?
1) Stall speeds are determined with the CG at the aft limit.
2) Minimum control speeds are determined with the CG at the forward limit.

Which statements are correct or incorrect?
1) Stall speeds are determined with the CG at the forward limit.
2) Minimum control speeds are determined with the CG at the forward limit.

Which statements are correct or incorrect?
1) Stall speeds are determined with the CG at the aft limit.
2) Minimum control speeds are determined with the CG at the aft limit.
The effect on static lateral stability of an aeroplane with a high wing as compared with a low wing is:

options.text: no effect as it is only used to improve aeroplane loading.

variant.question: With a more nose heavy aircraft (CG moves forward), the negative force produced by the horizontal stabiliser...

options.text: the tailplane never produces a negative force.

variant.question: The pilot of a cargo aircraft if flying with a payload of 400 kg from A to B with the Centre of Gravity on the aft position. After unloading the 400 kg of cargo at the destination airport, the CG moves to the forward limit. What changes can the pilot observe on the return flight?

options.text: Stability stays the same since the centre of gravity stays within its limit.
Stick force doesn’t change since the centre of gravity stays within its limit.
Less stability, change in stick force.

variant.question: Which CG position with respect to the neutral point ensures static longitudinal stability?

options.text: CG ahead of the neutral point.
CG can be ahead of or behind the neutral point as long as the forward or aft CG limits are not exceeded.
CG and neutral point at the same position.

variant.question: The aft CG limit can be determined by the:

Refer to figure 081-24.
Which line in the diagram represents an aeroplane with static longitudinal instability at all angles of attack?

Refer to figure 081-24.
Which line in the diagram illustrates an aeroplane with neutral static longitudinal stability at all angles of attack?

Refer to figure 081-27.
<div>Which of these lines represents the longitudinal stability of an aircraft with the CG at the neutral point at low angles of attack?
An aeroplane, with a CG location behind the centre of pressure of the wing can only maintain a straight and level flight when the horizontal tail loading is:

options.text: upwards or downwards depending on elevator deflection.

variant.question: The maximum aft position of the centre of gravity is, amongst others, limited by the

options.text: required minimum value of the stick force per g.
maximum longitudinal stability of the aeroplane.
inability to achieve maximum rotation rate during take-off.

variant.question: The effect of the wing downwash on the static longitudinal stability of an aeroplane is:

options.text: smallest at high values of the lift coefficient.

variant.question:
The most aft CG location may be limited by:
1) insufficient stick force stability.
2) insufficient flare capability.
3) excessive in-flight manoeuvrability.
4) insufficient in-flight manoeuvrability.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
The contribution of the wing to the static longitudinal stability of an aeroplane:

options.text: depends on CG location relative to the wing aerodynamic centre.
depends on the wing location relative to the fuselage.
is positive if the wing has a positively cambered aerofoil section and the aerodynamic centre is ahead of the CG.

variant.question: An aeroplane exhibits static longitudinal stability, if, when the angle of attack changes:

options.text: the change in total aeroplane lift acts aft of the centre of gravity.
the change in total aeroplane lift acts through the centre of gravity.
the change in wing lift is equal to the change in tail lift.

variant.question: Fuselage contribution to directional stability is I. ... when its AC is II.... of the CG ?
For a normal stable aeroplane, the centre of gravity is located:

options.text: with a sufficient minimum margin ahead of the neutral point of the aeroplane.
between the aft limit and the neutral point of the aeroplane.
at the neutral point of the aeroplane.
aft of the neutral point of the aeroplane.

variant.question: If the CG is (1) of the CP position the wing moments are destabilising, and if it moves (2) positive static longitudinal stability increases.
Which part of an aeroplane provides the greatest positive contribution to static longitudinal stability?
An aeroplane has static longitudinal stability when the

options.text: Centre of gravity is in front of the neutral point.
Aerodynamic centre is in front of the neutral point.
Centre of pressure is in front of the neutral point.
Centre of pressure is in front of the aerodynamic centre.

variant.question: Considering an aeroplane’s manoeuvrability in pitch, the further forward the centre of gravity..

options.text: the less the manoeuvrability due to the increased static longitudinal stability.
the less the manoeuvrability due to the increased dynamic longitudinal stability.
the greater the manoeuvrability due to a longer elevator to CG arm, which increases the pitching moment.
the greater the manoeuvrability due to the increased elevator forces that can be achieved.

variant.question: (For this question use the image in the annex). Which line in the diagram illustrates an aeroplane which is statically longitudinally stable at all angles of attack?
What is the effect of a Centre of Gravity (CG) shift to a more aft location on the aeroplane's static longitudinal stability and on the required control deflection for a certain pitch up or down?

options.text: The static longitudinal stability is reduced and the required control deflection is smaller.
The static longitudinal stability is increased and the required control deflection is larger.
The static longitudinal stability is reduced and the required control deflection is larger.
The static longitudinal stability is increased and the required control deflection is smaller.

variant.question: If an airplane exhibits poor longitudinal stability in flight, what can be done to increase the stability?

options.text: Increase the horizontal stabilizer surface area.
Increase the range of movement of the elevator.

variant.question:
The CG of an aeroplane is in a fixed position forward of the neutral point 
Which of these statements about the stick force stability is correct?

options.text: An increase of 10 kt from the trimmed position at high speed has less effect on the stick force than an increase of 10 kt from the trimmed position at low speed.
Aeroplane nose down trim increases the stick force stability.
Maintaining a steady speed below the trim speed requires a push force.
Stick force stability is not affected by trim.

variant.question: The CG of an aeroplane is in a fixed position forward of the neutral point. Which of these statements about the stick force stability is correct?

options.text: An increase of 10 kt from the trimmed position at high speed has less effect on the stick force than an increase of 10 kt from the trimmed position at low speed.
Stick force stability is not affected by trim.
Aeroplane nose down trim increases the stick force stability.
Maintaining a steady speed below the trim speed requires a push force.

The slope will increase as the CG moves (2) _____.

If the static lateral stability of an aeroplane is increased, whilst its static directional stability remains constant, ..

options.text: its sensitivity to Dutch roll increases.
the nose-down pitching moment in a turn increases.

If an aircraft has static longitudinal instability, it:

options.text: will be dynamically stable only at low speed.
may or may not be dynamically stable, depending on momentum and damping factors.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 The line representing the effect of the tail on the longitudinal static stability of an aeroplane is line (1) __, and it has a (2) __ contribution.

Which line in the image represents an aeroplane with static longitudinal instability at all angles of attack?

Consider a conventional aircraft with positive stability in its roll, pitch and yaw axes. During flight the Centre of Gravity (CG) moves aft. Due to this CG shift, the longitudinal stability (1)___ and the directional stability (2)___.

An aircraft departs with MTOW and with the CG on the aft limit. On the return flight, due to no payload being carried the CG shifts to the forward limit. How will the static stability have changed on the second leg?

options.text: CG position does not affect stability.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 The line representing the effect of the tail on the longitudinal static stability of an aeroplane is line (1) _____, which has the same effect as a (2) _____ CG.
The distance between the aft CG limit and the CG Neutral Point in straight and level flight is called the:
(For this question use the image in the annex). Which line in the diagram represents an aeroplane with static longitudinal instability at all angles of attack?
(For this question use the image in the annex). Which line in the diagram illustrates an aeroplane with neutral static longitudinal stability at all angles of attack?
What is the effect of an aft shift of the centre of gravity on static longitudinal stability and the required control deflection for a given pitch change?

options.text: Static longitudinal stability reduces and the required control deflection reduces.
Static longitudinal stability increases and the required control deflection reduces.
Static longitudinal stability increases and the required control deflection increases.
Static longitudinal stability reduces and the required control deflection increases.

variant.question: When is the airplane longitudinal stable?

options.text: When the CG is in front of the CP/Neutral point
It is independent of the CG location
When the CG is at the CP/Neutral point
When the CG is behind the CP/Neutral point

variant.question: The stabiliser of an aircraft, whose CG is within the normal range, is mistakenly set with its leading edge at a more positive angle of incidence than required. As a result the pilot will encounter..

options.text: higher-than-normal control forces, which may lead to a later-than-normal lift-off.
lighter-than-normal control forces, which may lead to over-rotation.
higher-than-normal control forces but would require a shorter take-off run.
lighter-than-normal control forces requiring a longer take-off run.

variant.question: The stabiliser of an aircraft, whose CG is within the normal range, is mistakenly set with its leading edge at a more positive angle of incidence than required. As a result the pilot will encounter...

options.text: higher-than-normal control forces, which may lead to a later-than-normal lift-off.
lighter-than-normal control forces requiring a longer take-off run.
higher-than-normal control forces but would require a shorter take-off run.
lighter-than-normal control forces, which may lead to over-rotation.

variant.question: What is the effect of an aft shift of the centre of gravity on  I. static longitudinal stability and  II. the required control deflection for a given pitch change?
If the thrust line is above the CG, how will this affect the airplane?
If the thrust line is above the CG, how will this affect the airplane?
An aircraft is approaching to land with its CG at the FWD limit. Compared to a situation with CG at the AFT limit, the control forces in pitch during the flare will be ___ and V~REF~ would be ___ .

The forward and aft CG limits are determined respectively
by:

options.text:
Minimum control response and decreasing
stability

variant.question: Which of the following statements with reference to the relationship between V~MCL~ and CG location for a common airplane (e.g. A320 or B737) is correct?

options.text: The CG has no influence on VMCL
It depends on the airplane type.

variant.question: Which of the following statements with reference to the relationship between V~MCG~ and CG location for a common airplane (e.g. A320 or B737) is correct?

options.text: The CG has no influence on VMCG if within the permissible CG limits.
The CG has no influence on VMCG.
